data.text: Multi-Day Bikepacking/Touring: Wash the Bib Shorts, or Carry a Spare Pair?

Multi day adventures. With respect to bib shorts (or just padded shorts) what is the consensus on days of use Vs washing, do you bring a spare pair, look to wash in a stream or go posh and use a launderette? I did three days in one pair (showered each day) but...well yeah hence my asking the question ü§£ I'm thinking I'd do a handwash near water at camp overnight, but then you've got to get things dry. Carrying extra clothes uses precious space and weight. Thanks for the advice bikepackers üòÅ

I usually take 2 pairs, wear each for 2 days and then have a rest day every 5th day or so to wash both pairs ideally at a laundrette if one is available but otherwise in a sink. I would love to know what others do!
data.author: Helen Colson

data.text: I was sceptical about knowing what others do ü§£
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: I use wipes to clean the chamois and let it dry. I do carry an extra pair. As long as you clean the chamois and yourself you should be ok.
data.author: Juan Pacheco

data.text: Max 3 days from one pair. Ideally no more than 2 days. Bring a spare pair of short if you‚Äôve got space or find somewhere to wash them. Drying them overnight in the UK can be tricky though if it‚Äôs cold
data.author: James Stockton

data.text: whne you have not option to wash it spray it with hand sanitizer..mainly on butt part ;:)
data.author: Roman Pertzian

data.text: I go super light and so only the set of bibs I‚Äôm wearing. If I arrive in time to wash and dry then I do so. If not then it‚Äôs dirty gear the next morning :) 3 days is probably my record‚Ä¶.I think
data.author: Kieran David Barry

data.text: does super light bikepacking hamper your overall enjoyment of a tour? Generally speaking...
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: quite the opposite! Means I can cover decent distances. 140kms today for example üôÇ
data.author: Kieran David Barry

data.text: I did three days this weekend at a 100 miles a day, I feel my kit was heavy. I'm really struggling with being unprepared or over equipped. I can afford the space for more bib shorts, but I don't want to be there freezing or soaking wet if the weather turns in the Scottish Highlands.
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: yeah I‚Äôve also got 3000mts climbing today. And I‚Äôm in Colombia which is a very different kettle of fish from Scotland! Ps the weather WILL turn in the highlands üòâ
data.author: Kieran David Barry

data.text: horses and courses isn't it
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: Wash in the stream, roll it in a camp towel to get the most moisture out, sleep on them overnight.
data.author: James Folsom

data.text: I like this idea, but can see myself faffing about too much
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: I have a comfy saddle, so just wear ordinary shorts and boxers, wash as needed.
data.author: Nick Mandeville

data.text: I just can't
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: I was wondering about some clothing specific antibacterial spray, can get a 250ml bottle and spray the pad down each night.
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: I bring 2 bibs on multi-day bike pack trips. I carry baby wipes and sanitizer. I take off bibs for the day, wipe down the nethers and chamois, and let ‚Äòem hang inside out. Maybe clean up one time during ride day if needed. Always clean up good after üí©. Haven‚Äôt run into issues.
data.author: Bret H. Parke

data.text: that's what I think I'll end up doing. I'm wild camping across Scotland so I'm expecting to have wild washes during the day or at camp where I imagine I'll wash my gear too. Thanks though, it validates my expectations.
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: In summer, I take 2 pairs & hand wash a pair every 2 days. If it‚Äôs warm & windy, they‚Äôll dry overnight, but if not, I take them out to dry some more at my lunch stop or, if I‚Äôm not on a dusty trail, hang them on my bike to dry as I ride. If it‚Äôs cold or rainy, it can be a challenge to get them dry, but body heat dries them fairly quickly
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: I did find drying my micro towel and water shoes and socks on my saddle bag as I rode was very effective in warm sunny weather
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: I think you have to find out what works for you and what not. What you feel comfortable with and what not. To give an example: I just (almost) finished a bickpacking trip through France (one month in total) and I did two periods of 10/11 (?) days with just one set of cycling clothes, including bibs. No showers for a period of 8 days, no bath,‚Ä¶ as long as you stay outside, you don‚Äôt get remarks. Once inside, you notice you smell a bit ü§™. So what üòâ
data.author: Christoffel Janssens

data.text: euewww. You're lucky nothing important fell off!!
data.author: Gabi Wildbore

data.text: or I‚Äôve got very good bibshorts üòÇ
data.author: Christoffel Janssens

data.text: to some extent I agree. I'm not prudish, so happy to let my body be as it will. That being said, my planned trip I want to enjoy and not worry about bailing out due to unintentional comfort issues that can arise from less than ideal hygiene.
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: I totally agree. My situation was a bit exceptional. I was travelling alone, always outside. Ate and drank outside. Just went in a shop to buy food. I wanted to see how far I could push myself. I asked regularly at people if they smelled something or if they where uncomfortable with me. They said, they didn‚Äôt‚Ä¶.
data.author: Christoffel Janssens

data.text: of course, we all cycle for different reasons and with different frames of mind. No right answer to this. Your experience sounds equally enviable and exceptional.
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: üò≥
data.author: James Stockton

data.text: Good quality bib shorts make a big difference for me , especially when cycling from 5 to 7 hrs a day. Personal hygiene is up to each individual!
data.author: Chris Kelly

data.text: got some great shorts, but everything has it's limits
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: Does nobody dry laundry simply by attaching it on top of the bags while riding, as I always do? Ofcourse when it rains or the road is very dusty it doesn‚Äôt work, but works most of the time for me.
data.author: Wojtek Mszyca Jr

data.text: I learned this quickly when my socks and water shoes got saturated from the morning dew. Used the same to dry my towel too.
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: I use triathlon shorts. They are designed to dry quick. One pair for riding and the other pair drying on my back rack. Doesn‚Äôt take long for them to dry providing it‚Äôs not raining. I‚Äôm which case put the wet ones on anyway.
data.author: Kevin Wright

data.text: I wash every night. If shorts are still a bit wet in morning I just pull them on. They dry really quick once you wear them. No different from riding in rain really.
data.author: Graham Cullen

data.text: If you wash them, they need to dry before you put them back on or have another pair to wear while drying. Clean but wet or still damp chamois may cause a rash.
data.author: Andy Simmons

data.text: this is my root of concern. Tempted to buy a pair on route.
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: I ride in one pair, have one clean and dry for tomorrow, and have yesterday‚Äôs washed pair drying on the bike somewhere. But I can get by with only one jersey b/c I go with merino wool. Racers may think that‚Äôs too many shorts but I‚Äôm not trying to be ultralight. An extra pair of shorts is not a big deal to carry unless you‚Äôre ultralight
data.author: Andy Simmons

data.text: I'm certain I'll take an extra pair based on the comments. It's not like they're heavy.
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: Don‚Äôt be afraid to ride dirty man. It‚Äôs key for long hauls. I typically where one shammy/4 days of riding. This summer I‚Äôll do a long haul with access to town every 3 days and will wash one or both shammys twice a week! A treat compared to out west (USA) where you might not see another human for a week in some places. If you wanna carry less on the bike, you gotta get dirtier.
data.author: Jeff Glessing

data.text: fungal infections however....ü§î Yeah I get where you are coming from, there's a balance to be made.
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: Yes, be afraid of the bacterial infection that comes with it.
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: few things are less fun than saddle sores
data.author: Chris Thomas

data.text: Never had a fungal problem or a butt soreness other than the standard saddle soreness that comes from long rides. I hear that orange colored shammys by Pearl Izumi have the best padding. Unless you‚Äôre prone to fungal/bacteria weirdness you can easily get 4 days out of one shammy.
data.author: Jeff Glessing

data.text: Two pairs. Just use some soap and water and air dry try the first pair on the bike the next day. Shammy pads collect germs...if you get a saddle sore and it gets infected from wearing nasty bibs you might need medical attention.
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: I take 3 pairs while wearing one. I change every day. Laundry about every 3 days in a campground, hotel, or commercial laundromat. I machine wash and machine dry as I do at home. Never had a problem with bike clothes being damaged in a dryer‚Ä¶even a commercial one.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: I take two pairs. At night I wash the pair that I was wearing. If it is not dry in the morning, I can hang it off the back of my bike while I am riding the next day. I just alternate the two pairs every other day.
data.author: Sheila Kitchen Irvin

data.text: I will definitely be taking two pairs with me now. I'm far more appreciative of advice from ladies on hygiene matters ‚ò∫Ô∏è
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: haha make germs your friend cause if they can swim in the Gangees you should be ok
data.author: John Findlay

data.text: One pair - wash every night.
data.author: Sel Dixon

data.text: Two pair. Wash one every day and dry it on my bike
data.author: Gary McClintock

data.text: what do you use to wash with? I was thinking I'd use my soap I use to wash with.
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: I keep one extra pair. Change every day
data.author: Robert Loftin

data.text: I do extra pair so wash days, wear new next day so 1st can dry
data.author: Brandi Jackson Hodges

data.text: Y‚Äôall are some cushy bikepackers. I‚Äôve gone a week without seeing more than 5 or 6 people and changed clothes once.
data.author: Jeff Glessing

data.text: i will use the same bib, day after day, and go weeks between washing it. i keep myself clean instead. baby wipes after every poop and before bed every night. i will use a bandana placed over my junk after every pee to soak up all the "after-dribbles." I'll whip it out after mission complete to air dry. the thing will reek, but the chammy won't. a good chammy cream is key. i use deez nutz, which is so very aromatic, and full of essential oils that keeps my taint feeling fresh and keeps the saddle-sores away. putting it on is my pre-ride ritual, and gets me right in the zone
data.author: Brent Joly

data.text: I felt this should have worked for me too. However after a 3 day trip over 300+ miles I was developing a slight rash despite being as careful as you describe. I think this level of preparedness and spare shorts is where I need to be.
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: Brent, your details are amazing. Way to go all out man.
data.author: Jeff Glessing

data.text: i once got a crazy rash after i washed my chammy with a new detergent i wasn't used to. I'll wash it with dawn dish soap on tour, which leaves no soap residue. fragrant detergents like gain leave a residue behind by design, which can irritate skin when in the hot moist environment of a chammy with all that friction. something to consider
data.author: Brent Joly

data.text: One pair washed every night,, if not dry in the morning they are worn anyways as it doesn't take much for them to dry once being worn.
data.author: Roy Rix

data.text: Infinity saddle. No chamois needed. But before I got that, it would kind of depend on where I was. I like to set up camp relatively early in the day (3-4 pm) to give myself and whomever I‚Äôm with time to hang out and chat before turning in. If I was somewhere it wasn‚Äôt going to rain, I‚Äôd wash them in a water source, ring them out really well and hang them up on a clothes line in my tent and they‚Äôd be dry by morning, if not sooner. If somewhere humid or rainy though, I‚Äôd use wet wipes and just clean the pad itself.
data.author: Justin Ammerman

data.text: What packs are those btw? I like the minimalist look.
data.author: Justin Ammerman

data.text: These looks like restrap bike packing bags
data.author: Jake Feasey

data.text: Restrap I bloody love them!
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: I really like the look of these.Ôøº
data.author: Justin Ammerman

data.text: can't recommend them enough
data.author: Philip Walker

data.text: I bring a spare and wipe the current day's one with antibacterial wipes and hang it up overnight, unless the opportunity arises to wash it.
data.author: Beine√°n √ì hEid√≠n

data.text: Hand wash them when possible. If you can shower, you should hand wash your shorts too. Be sure to rinse all the soap out and squeeze the water out instead of wringing to save the fabrics
data.author: Jacob Ashton

data.text: The only time I wash mine during a tour is overnight while camping, if I‚Äôm somewhere with running water. I don‚Äôt carry an extra pair. HOWEVER, I also use a new adhesive/disposable liner every morning to greatly extend chamois life (and minimize chances of a UTI).
data.author: Carter AL

data.text: I take only 1 extra padded short with me, and I wash at the moment I hit camp(even before cooking) If it was raining and it will rain next day, why bother? if will be sunny I wear the clean one next day and if needed air dry the other at the top of my bikepack on the rack, works fine for me, same with socks!
data.author: Olie Gr√∏nn

data.text: Thank you everyone for your exceptional advice! Taking a second pair of shorts is certainly no hardship, so with a couple of wash stops and rotating the shorts I'm sure I'll last the week in some hygienic comfort. Thanks again to everyone who answered, helped and responded!
data.author: Philip Walker
